scenarios.text: Demonstrator is powered on; Wait for the admin PC to boot (ADMIN_PC_BOOTED_UP); Wait for the FETT Tool to start, and provision components (COMPONENT_PROVISIONED events); Once all cyberphys components are provisioned (CYBERPHYS_PROVISIONED), the demonstrator can be used.
Turn off the demonstrator, retaining no state.

The demonstator is on and operational (CYBERPHYS_PROVISIONED); Reset BeamNG (BeamNG_RESET), and start driving (BEAMNG_START_DRIVING); The driver drivers around in the simulator, until the fuel tank is empty (BEAMNG_EMPTY_TANK); The driver can use the Infotainment during the whole time, not only during driving.

The scenario starts the same way as BASELINE_DRIVE; except during the drive a hack is executed (HACK_DEPLOYED); The targeted baseline component is succesfully hacked, while the secure version of the component mitigates the hack; The security mode is switched between "secure" (SECURITY_MUX_SECURE_INFOTAINMENT, SECURITY_MUX_SECURE_ECU) and baseline by environmental factors outside the driver's direct control.

Lane Keeping Assist (LKA) feature in ECU SW is disabled, because the car doesn't have the necessary sensors (cameras) installed, but the ECU SW still contains the LKA code, as a result of poor SW engineering practices; When the ECU is hacked (HACK_DEPLOYED), the bit that disables the LKA feature is flipped and the feature is enabled; Because no camera is present and we intentionally don't include additional safety checks, the ECU sends CAN messages commanding the steering wheel to turn; This effectively causes the driver to lose control of the car during simulation; The only way to recover is to activate one of the "secure" security modes (SECURITY_MUX_SECURE_INFOTAINMENT, SECURITY_MUX_SECURE_ECU).

The hacker can overwrite the pedal position that the ECU SW reads from the physical pedals, and instead send either a random value, or set the value to 100%, which will correspond to fully pressed throttle; Pressing the pedals has no effect; The only way to recover is to activate one of the "secure" security modes (SECURITY_MUX_SECURE_INFOTAINMENT, SECURITY_MUX_SECURE_ECU).

The hacker can overwrite the pedal position that the ECU SW reads from the physical pedals, and instead send either a random value, or set the value to 100%, which will correspond to fully pressed brake; Pressing the pedals has no effect; The only way to recover is to activate one of the "secure" security modes (SECURITY_MUX_SECURE_INFOTAINMENT, SECURITY_MUX_SECURE_ECU).

This hack overwrites the position of the Transmission Shifter that the ECU SW reads; As a result, the car is put into neutral, the RPM spikes up, and the drag (or a collision) eventually stops the car; The driver can move the Transmission shifter, but it has no effect; The only way to recover is to activate one of the "secure" security modes (SECURITY_MUX_SECURE_INFOTAINMENT, SECURITY_MUX_SECURE_ECU).

The Infotainment system displays the current car position (either as GPS, or as X-Y coordinates); When this hack is deployed (HACK_DEPLOYED), the hacker can see the current car position in the hacker kiosk; This hack targets Baseline Infotainment Server if SECURITY_MUX_BASELINE or SECURITY_MUX_SECURE_ECU, and Secure Infotainment Server if SECURITY_MUX_SECURE_INFOTAINMENT; A variant of this hack is to show some other car data that is visible on the CAN bus (such as wheel speed, oil and water temperatures, etc.), a secret key stored in the Infotainment system for purposes of remote authentication, or simply a serial number/version of the Infotainment software (something that is not normally accessible over the network); Activating the "secure infotainment" security mode (SECURITY_MUX_SECURE_INFOTAINMENT) stops the hacker from seeing real-time information.

The Infotainment system plays one of a number of preset audio tracks when requested by the driver, at a volume requested by the driver; This hack forces the audio track to one that the driver did not choose and makes it impossible for the driver to change it; Activating the "secure infotainment" infotainment security mode (SECURITY_MUX_SECURE_INFOTAINMENT) restores control over the music.

If a compomemt monitored by FETT tool becomes unresponsive (the watchdog generated COMPONENT_ERROR), an error message is logged, an error message is displayed on SimPCDisplay and if the component can be reprovisioned, FETT tool starts the provisioning process; If the component cannot be provisioned (such as BeamNG), a message is displayed on SimPCDisplay, and the user is advised to restart the component manually.
If ECU SW encounters a sensor error, it displays a message on SimPCDisplay.

If an error occurs in any component of Simulator PC, and it is not possible to display messages, the Simulator PC has to be manually restarted; Whole CyberPhys demonstator should be restarted to get a good known initial state.
If there is an error on Admin PC, it has to be powered off and on again, as there is not much else that can be done.
